ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was a really nice course to take! Tumi is super awesome, and I touched up my stats, R, and international development skills! Super cool course in general.
Statistical modeling and regressions in R, writing a replication paper, research design, how causal inferences can be made

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very strong, primarily because it provides rigorous statistical training in the area of causal inference. Very cool replication papers as well. Learned a lot about human well-being, politics, and development in Sub-Saharan Africa. Weakness would be the coding session at the start - either too easy if you already know R, or too fast if you don't. Not sure what the instructor can do about this, though! Maybe make those sessions optional?

Strengths: Prof was super great and knowledgeable, very willing to help, very understanding
Weaknesses: too much reading and not enough digesting and applying the reading, too much workload is concentrated in the final project and not spread out through the year

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want to do causal stats in R, take this course! You won't regret it, even if you are a graduate student.
Yes.  Good overview of a lot of causal inference topics with applications.

As an intermediate level refresher course to statistical modeling I highly recommend it. Placing into the context of African politics and economy is good, too, though that was not a focus of the class. You need to be pretty good at stats and R already, because the course moves quickly and there isn't time to go over basics.
